text:
Reddish-brown with thin off-white head and mild lacing. Fruity, black currant, berry, mild floral, and sour. Medium body, sour and sweet balance, and mild sour finish. Medium carbonation and sour-bitter lingering finish. Nice

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Really tasty sour red. Dark and vinous. Fruit accents the maltiness. Courtesy of Josh in 2017.
Bottle thanks to Levi. Reddish brown pour with a small head. Toasted grain. Chewy malt. Tart red fruits. Some pennies. Mildly acidic. Strong carb. Nice.

2017 vintage. Pours a deep reddish brown from the bottle with bubbly tan head that leaves moderate lace. Aroma of dark fruit notes, acetic sour, and sweet maltiness. Taste is even more complex, nice acidic front end, cherries and plums in the middle, vanilla oak in the finish. A bit sweet, but very nice.

From a bottle, pours a reddish brown with a tan head. The smell is roasted dark malt, cherries, sweet and sour. The taste is wood, dark roasted malt, sour cherries with some chocolate and a tart, sour, dry ending. Light+ in body with average carbonation. I dont like this vintage as much as previous but its still quite tasty.

Bottle; pours hazy brown with an off white head; aroma of tart cherries, vanilla, wood, and a touch of vinegar; taste is tart cherries with some maltiness, vinegar, vanilla, and some wood notes; dry, tart finish with some lingering cherry and wood

12floz bottle not marked, but this is the 2017 vintage. Poured into a tulip glass, where little head develops. Color is dark garnet, and the aroma brings the hard candy, sour funk that I expect. Sweet and sour, but the sourness is foremost. The tart cherry flavor is supported by a good malt backbone, making the body lively, yet controlled. A pretty good sour brown that is worth a try, and perhaps look for in the future.

Bottle from trade, 2017 vintage. Pours semi-murky red/brown with beige head. Aroma is cherry, oak, plum, raisin, dark fruit, prominent tart notes, vinegar, very much a sour red/brown. Flavor is tart cherry, oak, a little aspirin astringency, dark fruit, plum, vinegary. Really nice.

I follow other recent raters in declaring this to be wonderful. The murky body offers a solid sour that resonates in my jaw rather than puckering my lips, and the fruits are juicy, layered and complex. Delicious beer, one I simply opened on a night when I was reading alone so that I didnt have to share.
Havent had many sours but this is fantastic. Deep cherry black color, tangy and tart mild sour cherry. Little bit of woodyness. Would be up for this again
Pours hazy brown with flat tan head. Aroma of red berries, red grapes, bretta, mild nuts. Taste is medium fruit tart followed by a light sweet finish. Light and crisp body with average carbonation.
From Bushel and Peck, Really quite nice, not too sour or sweet, noticeable oak. Serving: Bottle

A hazed dark reddish copper ale with a thin mocha head. In aroma, nice sweet cherry malt with light acidity, light funk, nice and smooth. In mouth, a nice sweet cherry malt with light butterscotch, coconut, light vanilla, light tropical fruit punch, surprisingly nice yet light bodied.

This is just simply a wonderful thing to drink. It is gently sour, it is zesty, it is a big happy spray on the palate and a big burst of bliss in the nose. Great, subtly restrained fruit; a perfect balance between evocative dryness and an unrealized hint of fruity sweetness (that thankfully never actually happens - - it remains dry and complex). This thing is just mystical. I call it a thing, and not a beer, because sometimes the word beer just gets in the way.

Aroma of tart cherries, barn yard funk, musty humid air, and baking spices. Deep redish brown color, with a thin off white head. Tart up front, with medium sweetness, followed by medium sour. Tart cherries, funky yeast, and candied sugar. Tart finish with a very slight bitterness....acidic. Thin mouthfeel. Finish is tart with acidic tones. Nice and complex.

July 28, 2015.Vintage 2015. Tasting at jtclockworks, thanks for sharing!
Hazy amber with a small frothy off-white head. Aroma is toffee, cherries, lemon and some sharp acetic notes. 
Taste is light to medium sweet, with toffee, berries, tart apple skins, cherries and vinegar.Dry fruity finish with a light toffee sweetness. Medium bodied, average carbonation. 
A bit too much acetic acid.

355 ml. split by 4 @ Sir Goatie McGoat S&G Tasting. Thank you Mathieu87 and/or PriorL! Pours bright red pomegranate with little white head. Nose is massively sour, harsh vinegar, very puckering, despite this, you get clear fruity notes, sour cherries. Taste is same, massively sour, vinegar, puckering but still big fruit qualities, sour cherries, pomegranate, sour puckering candy, sof carbonation. Interesting, rather harsh but also quite good with other qualities. Nice.

14 Mar 2016, bottle. label is red unlike the pictures. It has the copyright symbol but i think it is more recent than 2010. Got it in 2015. dark scarlet. nose is sweet, hints of balsamic, malty, sweet yeast. thin/med body and mildly fizzy. sweet, balsamic, banana yeast, faintly tart. nice.
Very nice stuff. Subtle and great balance. Apricot and plum with some tamarind. Pours maroon with decent head and lacing. Tangy finish. Nicely done. Bottle thanks to Arminjewell.
Bottle share. Tart, venous nature. Definite sour characteristics. Aroma and taste right in the wheelhouse.

12oz bottle. Pours a light mahogany with a creamy beige head that ends up in a ring around the glass. Sour cherry and unripe plums skins, slightly smokey and oaky presence mixed in with some caramel malt, bit of tartness, raisin, moderate carbonation and body, as it dries out on the palate you get more old cherry and as Calvin described "vomit". Apart from that taste at the end pretty yummy.
12oz bottle. Cloudy brownish red pour. Nice Flanders aroma, some cherries and wood. Taste follows with nice cherry finish. Really good stuff.

Bottle, with thanks to Mike. Clear ruby brown pour. Short lived brown head. Aroma reminds me of vanilla-spiked potpourri; some cherry (but strangely in an artificial cherry juice kind of way, which isnt what Im used to from New Glarus, even in their excellent, sweet fruit beers). Fruit leather, hints of smoke. Somewhat vegetal. Taste is moderately sweet with present but restrained tartness. Syrupy texture, medium+ body, soft carbonation. Overall: a rare miss.

Bottle shared thanks roger. Flanders red in all its glory. Cherry and or other dark fruit with some oak on the back end full sour on the nose. The flavor is amazing dark cherries dark fruit oaky wood lots of sour but not enough to pucker. Balanced so wonderfully. Could drink many of these.

355ml bottle enjoyed @ home, thanks to nofunsally. Pours murky reddish brown with an off-white head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is cherries, plums, apples, raisins, wet wood, vinegar, leather, vanilla and honey. Flavour is sour and medium sweet. Medium bodied, oily texture, fizzy carbonation. Finish is tart, light acidic, dry and dark dried fruits.
light beige head. murky red brown colour. aroma is pickles, sourish, rotten wood, glue, lactic acid. taste like aroma, quite good sweet sour balance. rather dense mouthfeel, soft carbonation. bottle

Bottle at home. Pours a murky brown, head flashes and dissipates quickly. Aroma is dried red fruits, leather, light vinegar, a bit funky. Taste is rasin, leather, dried fruits, faint vinegar, a bit of woody notes. Medium bodied, medium carbonation. Decent, but not really my favorite in this style.
Deep ruby and clearish. Aroma iberry , vinegar. Flavors are rich berries, vanilla, tart, very smooth, slightly funky but s delicious beer. Thanks adam, love me some ng

12-oz, capped, foiled. Pours a murky dark brown with a creamy but thin tan head. Big sweet nose, showing a nice combination of balsamic, berries, stone fruit, and a hint of red wine vinegar. Tart, sweet, and complex. Creamy medium body with soft carb. Berries, stone fruit, and vinegars return on the mid palate, along with a bit of woodiness. Strong biting tart finish.
second time I have had this. Better than ever. Better than a flanders. Hold this up of what sour can do.

This is from a 2010 Unplugged bottle I found in the back of the fridge. Muddy dark amber color with a small beige head. Nose of tart cherries. The flavor is dominated by the tart cherries with some wet oak and a bit of moldy earth. I dont get any smoke out of this. Im not a fan of sour beers but this one is okay. Now Im curious if it is any different fresh.

Draft. Opaque brown with thin light tan head and some lacing. Sour plum aroma. Sweet malt with sour apple, plum, and caramel in the finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark reddish brown with no head. The aroma is cherry, apple, smoke and Worcestershire. The flavor has got some toasty and slightly smokey malt, but turns nicely sour with some cherry and oak.

Brown, almost amber color with huge bubbles and nice effervescence. Head dissipates quickly. Smell is somewhat metallic, sour, and oak notes also. Taste initially is a great sourness that turns into a faint oak presence that could almost be seen as a sherry type taste as it lingers. 4/10

Cherry Rhubarb Barbecue sauce with a prickly terriyaki twang. Nice mouthfeel and a funkily confuzzling nose. a WTF if not an Enigma. Smoked Flanders? wut is dis. Hard to compare to anything, definitively a new glarus beer, but not as delicious as most of their standards.
Bottle from Ryan at Kickback. Pours a clear reddish brown. Holy mix of flavors. Aroma of pear and apple. Taste is cherry and raisin with sourness in there. Well balanced tartness. Really lovely beer.

Reddish brown with a light tan head. Tangy fruity aroma. Tart flavors with just a hint of cherry. Sourness is present but not overwhelming. A bit of nutty malt flavor. Lingering sourness on finish. Really nice.

Bottle to snifter (shared with the Mrs; thanks adnielsen). Looks good; a very cloudy amberish caramel with off-white head that quickly dissipates into very thin lacing. Smells semi-sweet and mildly tart with a nice cherry presence alongside mild notes of oak. Tastes like it smells with a bit more tartness and a pleasant medium-bodied mouthfeel. Enjoyable.

12oz bottle in a taster. Pours deep amber/brown with an off-white head. Aroma of sourness, some cherries, light oak, some pale and caramel malts, and some floral notes. Flavor the same with a nice blend. Average texture. A solid beer.

July 2, 2015 - bottle. Brown pour with nice head and lacing. Aroma was sour, fruity, oak and malt. Taste was a nice balance of the flavors from the aroma. Did not expect much of this and was pleasantly surprised.
Slight pickle smell. Slight apple taste almost like Serendipity and a slight sourness. Its like a cross between their Apple Ale, their Wild Sour, and maybe Serendipity.

Bottle shared. Pours hazy red amber with a short lived tan head. Aroma of tart red fruit, soft vinegar, light vinous notes, light oak and some sweet malt. Flavour is moderate sweet and sour. Medium bodied with very soft carbonation.

Bottle shared thanks to kermis. Beautiful reddish brown with short lasting off white head. Red berries, strawberry yoghurt, thin red wine, milky, funk, straw, wood, old strawberries, balsamico. Medium sour with light sweetness. Light to medium bodied with soft but fizzy carbonation.

bottle coirtesy of and shared with Kermis.
Head disappears very quickly. Funky aroma. Clear red pour. Sour.

Reddish brown. Aroma of Balsamic vinegar. Taste- tart cherry, green apple, blueberry, red wine and more of that Balsamic Vinegar. Laid down on top of a mellow cereal malt. I really like Sours and this is top-notch. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Reddish brown pour with a thin head that fades quick. Slightly tart aroma. Light mouth. Taste is perfectly tart. Hints of raisin, vanilla and wood. Some berries going on as well. Very drinkable.

12 oz. bottle, consumed on 6-7-15. Pours a medium brown with a small amount of taupe head. Hazy. Copper to reddish hue. Nice color, but I wish there were more head. Tart, raspberry, rhubarb aroma. A bit of balsamic vinegar in the smell, but not in a bad way. Dusty, musty smell. Smells very good. Tart, lightly sour flavor. Spicy, hot finish features cinnamon and cloves. Chemicals. All of these effects are very good. Rhubarb and tart raspberry in the flavor as well. Tart in a dull way in the aftertaste (not boring dull but rather subdued dull). Nice, sharp, fluffy palate. Easy to drink. Just a darn good beer across the board. Complex and likable in all ways. Better than I remember from previous bottles, although I have liked each of them. All that said, it doesnt blow me away in any facet.
Reddish brow pour, fairly large head. Sour cherry predominately in the aroma and taste. Toffee, slightly jammy, not as acidic as other new glarus fruit or sours. Medium body.

New Glarus Enigma has a thick, frothy, off-white head, a mostly clear, red-orange-brown appearance, some lacing left behind, and no noticeable bubbles. The aroma is of sharp, oaked, sourness, some sugar, citrus juice, and brown bread. Taste is the same, with a coconut and stomach acid component. Mouthfeel is medium, and New Glarus Enigma finishes puckering, tart, and sip-able. RJT
Red brown with big bubbles. Tart cherries, wood, strawberry rhubarb pie, dry cider and a little grassy. Tart, apple flavor that is dry. Medium body with an acidic, clingy feel.

Bottle:
Pours deep copper/berry-red with a small, off-white head.
Cherry aroma...with hints of cinnamon.
Taste is cherry malt, wood....tart...caramel malt, dried sweet fruits.
Very tasty.

From a 12 oz split into 2 snifters. Aroma is wild brett yeast. Flavor is tart but bearable. Well balanced tartness with depth of maltiness and a backbone of spice. Nice sour, but a little middle of the road to truly be amazing.
Bit of a wine nose to it and at first taste a bit of a cider flavor. Not overly tart, but has some funk to it. Fruity and light.
12oz bottle pours out a mahogany topped with a sand head. Nose is like old over ripe orange a nice tartness. Taste is more of the fruit and a good light tartness.

Shared at the Alpha Brewery tap room, thank you Derrick! Deep reddish amber copper colour with sudsy beige foam and fine Belgian lace. Husky grains, hint of caramel and toffee, strong chocolate notes, nutty, subtle hop bitterness and black pepper notes. Intense dark cherry impression, adding yet more complexity. Loads of cool yeast esters and phenols. Beneficial hardwood traits. Clearly aged but not excessively oxidized. Tart, tangy, bewilderingly delicious.

Bottle. Pours ruby, off white head with lacing. Nose has complex acidity reminiscent of cherry or plum sauce reduction and mild, almost sweet, notes of acetic acid, some bright earthiness as well. Flavor is very nicely balanced, quite dry, starts with lightly sweet cherry-pie like notes, middle is solid barley backbone, fresh and bready, ends with a puckingly tart finish. Great stuff.

Bouteille 355ml, gracieuseté de tom10101, merci Tommy! Couleur rouge translucide, anneau de mousse blanc cassé. Arôme de canneberge, cerise, coté funky, malt. Goût de cerise, Brett, canneberge, bonne acidité, boisé en fin de bouche. Carbonatation moyenne-faible, corps moyen.

12oz bottle pours with a murky amber body that supports a thin tan head. The aroma offers up sourness, a nice spicy malt sweetened woodiness, some cherry juice and a tad earthy agedness. The taste has mild puckering notes, a bit of sour cherry and then modestly sweet cherry juice. To midway a woody sort of spicy wood note just peaks up over the other flavors. Into the finish it tries to have a moderate sour yet sweetened vinegar sensation but instead it just lightly murmurs away off in the background.
Reddish brown. Quite fizzy. Very sour with lots of cherry taste and some woodiness. Hooray.
Bottle thanks to my wife. Garnet with a tan head. Tannins, cherries and dark red fruits. Tart and slightly funky in the best way. Outstanding.
Thanks for west for checking this one of the list. A little tart. A little gritty and earthy. Cherry and fruit atoma. Pretty nice. Smooth.
Bottle courtesy unknown. Pours a reddish brown, little to no head. Aroma latex paint, ethanol, cherry syrup. Body lively, finish tannic and slightly spicy. Meh.
12o bottle pours a reddy brown color without much of a head. Mild sourness and some nice brown ale flavors.

Probably one of the best sours I've had. Bottle pour at Toefflers in new glarus. Dark red with no head. Sweet fruity raspberry and raisin aroma. Cherries and raspberries dominate the taste. Not a "puckery" sour - just fruity and delicious.
March Ale Alpharetta. Damn I like me some New Glarus. Lots of sour cherries and oak. Bits of vanilla add to the depth of medium sour cherries. Lively carbonated palate. Good stuff.
I didnt read the label all the way to the bottom, so the fact this is a sour ale was quite shocking. After the initial shock passed it was ok

Poured from bottle to glass. Copper red hue with creamy tan head that dissipated to a thin ring. Aroma is huge clove, balsamic, caramel. Mouthfeel is ok with medium light body x d soft carbonation. Taste is dry sweet with a chemical following. Overall this beer is kind of disjointed and overly-clove like

Pours slightly hazy mahogany with a fairly thick light tan head. Malty aroma has a cedar overtone. FlVor is mainly sour cherries but not make-your-face-do-calisthenics sour; a bit of fruity sweetness peeps through, as well as woody and malty tones. Fairly fizzy texture is somewhat firm. No enigma here - bottoms up!

12 oz bottle - pours a lighter brown . Mil vinegar aroma , tart cherries refreshing sour finish . Very good . 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The best of the New Glarus beers. Taste is a mix of a sweet citrus ale and sour but sour is not overwhelming. Good beer for a cool fall day.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Pours clear reddish caramel colored with very thin off white head. Nose is mild vinegar with little malt. Taste is vinegar up front then tart cherry and then some sweetness. Good.

Bottle: Thanks, Jeff. Solid copper body with deep amber edges & modest clarity. Soapy, thin, gray-tinted layer of foam on top. Ripe, tart apple aroma up front that quickly gets usurped by a strong foundation of white wine grapes, wet oak, black cherry skins, & mild lactic acidity. Not as sour as the aroma would have you believe, but it seems more complex & layered on the palate. Candied apples, apple cider vinegar, bready toasted malt, faint cinnamon, red grapes, oak, a hint of vanillin, tart & under-ripe prune, & a bit of faint caramel. Nice sourness balanced with sweetness from start to finish. Acidic, but juicy enough to blunt things nicely. Hint of yogurt & lacto in the drying, grape skin & warm oak finish. Really nice stuff.

12 oz bottle, poured into a tulip glass at approximately 40 degrees F.

Appearance: Pours a deep, dark ruddy brown, with a head that dissipates rather quickly.

Smell: Balsamic vinegar notes waft out of the glass first, of course, followed by notes of cherry and sweet caramel. Faint hints of something akin to hardwood also come along for the ride.

Taste: Now thats a good, approachable, fruity oud bruin. Sour vinegar strikes first, overlaying every other aspect of the taste with its essence. Cherry and berry flavors dance to the balsamic tune, occasionally forming some hints of currant and plum, while sweet caramel plays a soft counterpoint in the background.

Mouthfeel: Medium and drinkable.

Overall: Decidedly tasty. Would repeat frequently, if I were nearer the Wisconsin border. Which I may be fairly soon, so Ive things to look forward to!
Shared bottle. Awesome treat, huge character of tart cherry, touch of vanilla funk and gentle sour finish. Outstanding fruity wild ale.

Pours the color of dark toffee, extremely minimal head. Nose is quite like those cans of dark cherries in syrup we had as kids, dont know if that even exists anymore. Nose translates through to the taste, with that awesome dark cherry joined by moderate funk and acidity. Lively palate, leaves a slightly syrupy coating afterwards. Really enjoyable.

The beer is brownish maroon with a tan head. Looks fairly cloudy but its a pretty dark beer. The aroma is mostly apple sauce. Some apples. Mild vaguely oud bruin sweetness with very mild sour note. Mildly sour taste. Milder apple sauce flavor but still definitely still in that sphere. Some crystal malt sweetness. Fairly light body. Really an odd beer. Im not much of a fan.
Bottle at Craigs. Pours hazy murky amber, sweet cherry, almond and vanilla. Tasty sourness.

12oz bottle into tulip. Minneapolis. 

Pours ruby-brown, transparent, with small offwhite head. Very little retention.

Aroma is musty, earthy, tart cranberry, a little woody. 

Taste is tart all the way through, a little sweetness in the finish too. 

Medium body, thick texture, light carbonation, long finish. 

A really well rounded, nicely made sour.

[Bottle] Pours a dark ruby color without any head. Nose is of oak barrel, cherry, sour dark fruits and light vanilla. Flavor notes include dark fruit, oak chips, cranberry, tart cherries, light vanilla and sour apple. Not very tart or sour overall. Decent palate. Looking forward to aging a few bottles and seeing where this goes.

Holy hell is this good. Fell in love with Cran-bic, but I might just like this bettery. Poured dark brown with a red hue. Bready sour cherry aroma. Has that light "musty" lambic note. Taste is huge cherry, with hints of vanilla and caramel. Good sour bite, but balanced well by the sweet bread yeast taste. Amazing!
Twelve ounce bottle from Timfoolery, pour is reddish-brown, very little head, tart, nice bite.

Drinking a 2010 in 2014, so take it for what its worth. Upfront - its really good. Pours clear red-gold with moderate light tan cream head; nice residual lacing. Particularly aromatic - ripe tart cherries with an underpinning baked malts. Flavors are rich and complex. The fruit carries through, and adds a faint smokiness. The palate is rich yet not heavy. Its in the sour category, and it qualifies, yet it has this rich mouth coating unctiousness normally associated with sweeter ales. Enigma. Very nice New Glarus......

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2015 "noticeable vanilla in the aroma and flavor. i like wood, but i think it this case it was a little too much, and made the beer a good/very good beer, when it had the potential to be a phenomenal beer. vanilla, oak, and funky cherry aroma. body is smooth with a lactic quality. flavor like the aroma, pretty well balanced sweet and sour, with the cherry coming through a little. id have liked it more sour. it was tart, but not quite sour. super smooth though, and a solid brew. thanks again to pfoxyjohn for this tasty elixir. Belgian Red still king, though."
This newest batch was even better.  More oak funk and cherry.  Up a tenth.

Bottle share at NG Wild Peach release. Pour is hazy red/brown with a very small white head. Aroma and flavor are fruit forward - red apples, cherry, slight caramel, grapes, wood, and orange tang. Finish is slightly sour but still fruit forward.

Bottle thanks to nuplastikk. Poured a hazy dark brown red with thin beige head. Aroma pretty sweet very light sour not fruit forward but some cherry. Light carb need bod. Sweet caramel brown sugar taste.

Bottle shared by Rusty. Pours a deep amber with a one finger head. The nose is raspberries, faint sour cherry, wood. The taste is raspberries, slight dried fruit rinds, like funk. Not as sour as the 2006 version, but still a nice. 3.8
At my place with Matt, Kristin, Jake, Jacob and Taylor. Pours.bronze orange. Aroma is sugar sweet apple. Taste is apple, sweet apple.

Bottle courtesy of tkrjukoff. Pours tiny hazy reddish golden with a small offwhite head that quickly dissipates without leaving any trace on the glass. Smell is sour and slightly fruity with caramel, biscuits, rhubarb, strawberries, hay, rosé wine, lime juice, lemon zest, raspberry jam, cinnamon, vanilla custard and hints of glue and acetic acid. Taste is slightly sweet, sour, tiny malty and fruity with biscuits, lemon juice, lime juice, hay, moist wood, rhubarb, wild strawberries, raspberry jam, moist soil, leather, orange zest, lemon zest, red wine vinegar, vanilla and hints of caramel, cinnamon and sweet dark bread. Mouthfeel is round, tart, slightly dry, tiny mouth-puckering and medium bodied. Finish is sour, tiny malty and fruity with dark bread, biscuits, lime juice, red wine vinegar, moist hay, leather, strawberries, rhubarb and red wine vinegar. Exceptionally fruity Flanders red, what strawberry rhubarb should have been like had it been great.

4 year old rot box scope. Not sure why Ive kept this with me for that long, would mean it has traveled to 4 different apartments/houses with me. Odd. This beer poured reddish brown, clear, not much of a small off white head. Aroma was actually pleasing. Cherry skins, a touch of caramel and toffee, a bit of apple. Flavor...not bad. Slightly tart. Rich. Bigger, almost chewy mouthfeel. Tart, but not bracing. Im puzzled, old beer is gross, but this beer did not show many signs of being both old and (most likely) mishandled. Peted fine, which was tame where I was @ just last night.
Reviewed from notes: 2010 bottle; pours almost a brown color with off-white head. Tartness on the nose, some oak, vanilla, and darker fruits; follows onto the palate. Finishes tart and dry.

2010 vintage bottle from the cellar. Pours a murky mahogany with him light tan head. Nose some cherry soured fruit, vanilla and oak. Taste pleasing sour funk up front, then the fruit and caramel notes. Syrupy mouth. Finish with some tart notes and lingering vanilla. Tastes better now than it did fresh as I remember.

Bottle (2010 Unplugged) shared at DC Annual Epic Sour Tasting, thanks maniac! Caramel brown with off-white head. Aromas of caramel, sweet fruit, syrup. Tastes of caramel, sweet dark fruit, oak, vanilla. Medium-light body with a dry finish. Interesting beer.
From a bottle shared at the DC Epic Sour Beer Tasting. Pours a hazy gold with an off white head. Hoppy nose. Caramel and tart cherry flavors.

Sour cherry, caramel aroma... Hazy caramel red brown in color... Flavor is sweet caramel, notes of vanilla, oak, cherry... Tartness, vinegar on finish... Amazing

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2010 Unplugged bottle thanks to Jeff for sharing. Pours a mostly clear red color with a small fizzy head. Aroma is cherries, bread, apples, and light sour funk. Taste has a nice sweet and tart balance. Mostly cherries with some honey and wood. Almost tastes like a mead but just a little less sweetness. Really good.

bottle via trade. forgot where from. pours a brownish red with minimal head that dissipates in no time. aroma of cherries, cranberries, some apple. Taste is a little on the sweet side with not much actual sourness. actually tastes more like one of their fruit contraptions than a sour. hmmmm. still delish but just not sour. actually...is this serendipity? really, as I drink it I dont get much sourness at all. very weird. I had this beer a while ago and much more sour.

12oz bottle, thanks to nuplastikk. Not sure what the vintage was, uploading rate from notes. Totally hazy dark brown red color. Little off-white head. Good ropes and bits of lace. Bigger body. Smooth, lighter carbonation. Lightly slick texture. Good vanilla, tasty caramel syrup. Nice dark fruit, light spicy barrel notes. Moderate sweet taste, light sour. Tasty, complex oak barrel-aged sour brown.

Nice extra from Guerde-thanks! 2010 bottle.  Pretty light reddish brown. Totally clear and light carbonation. Cherry nose, with vanilla and oak. Flavors of sweet and tart cherry, light oak. Short and not very complex. Tasty but a bit overrated.

Unsure of bottle date. Checked the Fresh Beer Only page and it didnt really help. Heres the code on the bottom of bottle, not other marking indicating date: 8361 B-21350

Only thing I can think is this was bottled late December, 2008.

A: Pours a rosey orange ale with excellent clarity and a transient single finger tan head. Rings of lacing. Sheet of light tan head.

S: cherries, allspice, clove, the cherries remind me of a cherry jolly rancher or some cough syrup. Just a hint of vanilla stemming from the oak.

T: Cherries, oak, yeast. Semi-tart up front with plenty of sweetness through the center. The fruit has taken on plenty of mineral-like flavors. Meh. Tastes like mulled wine.

M: Light syrup feel with low carbonation. Finish is slightly cloying but short lived. 

O: Plenty fruity, but pretty much ends up tasting mulled wine. Probably would be good served warm.

Serving type: bottle

07-13-2011
Amber/orange, hazy, off-white head. Aroma: lightly sour, toasty malts, some tart cherry, earthy notes. Flavor is similar, with toasty malts, earthy, woody notes, some tart cherry.

12oz bottle thanks to matboz! Pours cloudy brownish red with small head. Nose is tart berry, funky oak, apple. Taste is fruity cranberry, rasberry, cherry, light funk, tiny bit of acidity. Finish is mild tart berry, oak, with nice vanilla notes from the barrel. Very thrist-quenching, very enjoyable.

A: Ruby Hue, Passes Some Light, White Head Ring that quickly disapates, No Lacing

S: Cranberry, Tart Cherry

T: Tart Cherry, Cranberry, Mild Red Plum

M: Medicore Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Tart

Overall, a pretty nice and easy drinking Oud Bruin but definitely a little over rated in my opinion. The carbonation has more of a cherry pop flavor at times when it warms up.

Pours a dirty reddish brown with a small white ring. Aroma is tart cherry and light vineagar. Taste is surprisingly smooth. Tart cherry and oak balance really well. This is a few years old so everything is very well balanced and smooth. Not overly puckering but very easy drinkable.

2012 bottle.Aroma is fairly fruity with some cherries and tart berries, but the most dominant aroma is oak and its characteristics - faint vanilla but more smokey. Not much malt character to the aroma, more a bit stale than I expected.Pours a slightly cloudy amber brown with some red highlights. Small, moderately thick head that recedes to the edges very quickly. Flavor is a balanced blend of fruit and oak with a light acidity. Slight sweetness upfront with some cherry syrup notes. The sweet cherries are balanced with the oak adding a light smokiness. The oak flavor is more similar to fresh cut oak than cured oak so I don?t pick up much vanilla. Faint bitterness and a touch of a red apple flavor.Mouthfeel is medium light bodied with medium carbonation. Low acidic astringency with low alcohol warmth. Returns a King! Enigma is back for the fall of 2012 following a brewing in 2010 and 2006 under New Glarus now defunct Unplugged Series label. Im always psyched to see a New Glarus beer make a return that I never got a chance to try before it sold out in stores. 

It starts off with a clear, reddish/orange color with only a slight head. The scent is sweet yet sour to the nose as it picks up hints of yeast, cherry, and other fruity scents. A very strong and yet intriguing smell.

In the realm of Sour Ales, this one is pretty tame to the taste buds. The texture is smooth and easy drinking. There is a bold sweet and sour flavor that makes this beer taste great! Im not really sure if this is a beer or a little piece of heaven in my pint glass as it makes for a rather complex taste indeed, well deserving of the name Enigma. 

Yeah, its pretty awesome guys! The Sour Ale is not a widely made beer, but when its done well its delicious. Overall this is good beginner level Sour Ale as there are far stronger sours on the market. Being a 90s kid, sours always have a place in my heart as they remind me of a Sour Apple Warhead that was so popular when I was a kid. Smooth, refreshing, and delicious makes this beer a must try before its gone.

Enjoyed in a wine glass at fridge temp. Cloudy plum appearance with minimal carbonation. Purple ruby red and brown all in one glass. Flanders red almost standard rodenbach scent. Oak and cherries are strong on the nose. Very overpowering cherries. Too sweet. Not a lot of smoke or vanilla as the label suggested. Mild mouthfeel and carbonation.
Bottle. Brown pour with tons of lacing. Fruity nose with some vinegar. Very tart with lots of apple. Finishes sweet.

Bottle courtesy of mdfb79. Thanks Dan! Shared with my wife during the Chicago Bears victory over Green Bay on MNF.

A: Orange hue with a thin beige head that barely leaves any lacing.

S: Cherries, oak, Flanders oud bruin?

T: From the first sip, this immediately tastes like a New Glarus beer. Its too sweet. I was really hoping that this would walk the sweet / sour tightrope, but it heavily favors the sweet side. Cherries with hints of oak make up the bulk of the taste. The taste itself seems confused and trapped between styles. It has elements of a Flanders oud bruin and a sweet NG fruit beer, but turns out to be neither. Its not bad or wrong because it doesnt fit perfectly into a style, it just doesnt taste that great. Its pretty average.

M: Thin, too sweet.

D: Even one small bottle was plenty for me. Thanks, but no thanks.
Nose is rich vanilla and strong cinnamon. Sweet maltiness. Tich malt flavor and slight tartness with lots of vanilla and spices. This is NOT sour at all. what the fuck? No funk, no sour.

(Bottle) Pours dark copper with a small sand coloured. The aroma holds coconut/buttery oak and pineapples up front with undertones of apple cider, mild citrus, toasted bread, bread, old milk, vanilla, wet stone and dirt. The flavour is light sweet and medium acidic with almost no bitterness. Notes of citrus, tart tropical fruits, buttery/coconut-driven oak, dirt, apple cider, sour milk and bread. The mouthfeel is round and tart with a soft carbonation. Oaky and citric fruity finish. Near medium bodied.

Originally reviewed: 9/17/10. I have been wanting to try this beer for awhile, so when I heard Dan was releasing this again due to popular demand, I was super pumped. 12oz bottle poured into a pint glass. 

The color of this beer is not what I expected. Yields a dark rusty copper color with a thin beige head on top. Some light lace sticks around, but nothing too sticky. I love the nose on this. Getting notes of apples, cherries, tart cranberries, oak, and damp trail. Splendid.

The mouth is firm, slightly wet, but filling enough. Carbonation level is spot on for a fruit beer. Lightly spritzy, but not overly so. Smooth flavors of cherry, cranberry, wood notes, and faint funk on the back end. The finish is a little tamer than some of his other fruit beers, but its got a pleasantly tart aftetaste. Wow. This was everything I was hoping it was going to be. Again, I am amazed at Dans work. The man knows his way around fruit beers for sure.
tart cherry and biscuit aromas. slight acetic with a malt backbone. easy drinker, slight sour on the backend, reminiscent of cherry pie but in a good way. 2010 bottle.
12 ounce thanks to mashmaster. Big sour cherry beer. Tart and carbonated. That big of vinegar balanced by the sour cherry. Awesome, as usual.

12 ounce bottle. Pours a cloudy amber with a thin white head. Fruity, tart, malty. A nice Flanders beer. I would like to see a little more complexity, but that is not a deal breaker. This beer is solid.

From notes.  First reviewed 6/9/2010.  11 oz. pour in a snifter on tap at Uncle Mikes.

My pour has a Ruby Red color with a brown tint. A fizzy off white head arrives on tap, sticking around for a bit and leaving some nice lace.

The aroma is sweet and tart cherry, a touch of vinegar, and a bit of oak.

Strong tart cherry taste starts strong and slowly fades as the my tongue is made aware of the sweetness. Mild balsamic flavor for a bit, and some oak as well. Cherry all the way through.

Very crisp carbonation causes my tongue to tingle for a bit. Medium / light body. Could be a bit more substantial.

Goes down easy. The fruity and sweet aftertaste, along with a light puckering sourness helps to prepare me for the next sip.

Great beer!  Aroma and taste are reminiscent of sour cherry cobbler.  Really nice oaky spicyness goes well with the cherries and tartness of the beer.  New Glarus is becoming one of my favorite breweries.
Bottle thanks to wavers!! Cherry and cinnamon. Great vanilla and oak flavors. So  much cherry. Love it!

In the smell you would think this is a sour beer, with sour cherries, apples, and brett character but the taste changes a bit when all those ingredients are mixed in with caramel and subtle hints of chocolate.

Pours an opaque amber/chestnut color with a medium tan head.  Aroma has nice sour vinous/earthy notes, sweet cherry, and oaky vanilla.  Flavor is complex...leathery sour notes, musty hops, sour cherry, and oaky vanilla.  Mouthfeel is light and lively and the finish is dry with vanilla/oak and a hint of cherry.  Wow.

Thanks to ryan or GT2 for this one? This one strikes me as better than the older, 7% version. A more complex and nuanced dark fruit profile mixes with great tart oud bruin presence, touches of balsamic (but in the good way, like Earthmonk), and that great tart cherry. Sweet, but the tartness cuts through it and provides quite a nice mouthfeel. A marked improvement over the 2006, in my opinion.
Brown pour with a thin light tan head.  Malty aroma with a bit of molasses, grain, and caramel, maybe even some maple syrup.  Very sweet flavor with light tartness.  Caramel, oak, vanilla, and cream.

Bottle This beer rocks! Clear copper ale with a small, fizzy, white head. The bouquet is a funky, fruity mélange of wood, cherries and funked-out socks. Full-bodied with a velvety mouthfeel and vibrant carbonation. The flavor presents cherries, yogurty lactic acid, vanilla and caramel. Tangy-sweet, fruity finish. Thanks so much to biggsbowler for sharing this world class bottle of beer!

This poured a murky lighter brown colorw ith a beige head. Aroma was of light vinegar, light musty fruit, some funk, and yeast. Flavor was not overly tart, but definitely sour, some nice cheesy funk with cobb webb basement taste too. PRetty decent.

12 ounce bottle that poured a cloudy amber color with aromas of tart cherries, wood, and some acidic notes.  Taste is tart cherries, oak, vanilla, and some funkiness.  Really great beer that I wish I had more of, after each sip, I wanted more.

Bottle.  Pours a bright and clear dark copper to amber body with a very minimal fizzy head that vanished immediately save for a very thin ring.  The nose is deeply fruity with cherry, rivaled by a fairly heavy woodiness.  Theres a touch of light sourness, but minimal, and the beginning of a little oxidation as well.  The flavor is pretty nice, just the right balance between the bugs and the wood, Not overly sweet up front, but it comes out on the finish nicely, complementing the cherry flavor and giving it a nice sour cherry pie filling quality.  I really like the woody flavors in this, reminds me of some of the authentic Belgian versions.  Much better than most American efforts.  Medium bodied with a nice thick almost chewy texture and moderate fizzy carbonation.  Pretty nice beer.

(12oz bottle courtesy of nuplastikk!).  Pours a hazy orange-brown color with off-white head.  Active carbonation.  Aroma has vanilla, wood, cherry and other darker pit fruit.   Taste is both sweet and sour--and quite rich.  Medium bodied with a slick mouthfeel.  Smooth, delicious finish.  Really nice.

Very complex malty, tart, fruity aroma.  Lots of vanilla, sweet malts and sour cherries, rich.  Pours a murky brown with a moderate fizzy off-white head, fairly good retention, spotty lacing.  The first thing that strikes me in the flavor is rich, smooth vanilla and cherries, both sour and sweet.  Very nice balance between the tart, complex sour component and rich malty notes.  Earthy, some tobacco, sweet malt and cherry notes fade into a mellow, smooth, dry finish.  Medium body, very smooth, moderate carbonation.  Excellent brew, just the right balance of sour, fruit, and rich malts, well done.

Bottle shared with GT2. Pour is a most clearly ruby/pink color with a modest white head, some lacing/retention. Nose is big on all types of spices: cardamom, clove, cinnamon, nutmeg, vanilla, oak. Really nice. Taste is even better: lots of sour cherries and chai tea, oaky notes. Lots of clove, cinnamon, and nutmeg linger. Palate is clean, soft, with a long finish. Outstanding. Probably the best beer of the tasting.

Bottle from Breeze Thru.  Pours a pale reddish brown with an off white head.  Lightly carbonated.  Aroma is sweet malt, sour cherries, earth and wood.  Taste is tartly cherry, sweet caramelness, bread with oak thickness in the background.  Finishes lighter than it seems.  NG knows their fruit beers.

355mL thanks to one of my many trade partners. The pour is a clear, light reddish color (near pink) with a healthy, yellow head. Nose is incredible: wildly sweet and rich baked cherries with barleywine like notes of toffee, butterscotch, vanilla. Whoa. Taste....holy god. Amazing play between sweet fresh red fruit explosion and quenching sourness with no acid palate. Rather there is that enigmatic, no pun intended, New Glarus sour palate you get in the Old English Porter that is almost indescribable. It is rich and thick feeling, but also quenching and sour with mild anesthetic, clovey Christmas spices. So delicious. Overall, feels like New Glarus Belgian Red on crack with the palate perfection of New Glarus Old English Porter. Wow..
was not a fan of this beer at all. Sour and brown are far from favorites of mine.
12oz traded bottle. Compared to the 2006 version: less sour, more wood & vanilla from the barrels, and ends sweeter from the cherries. A little lighter overall. Pleasant.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2012 Aroma is awesome lots of oak with some cherry and vanilla.  Pours A golden amber color. Small off white head that dissipates quickly. Medium carbination. Tart cherry and Sour but not overly sour up front, gives way to oak and vanilla, with a slight smokeyness. Finishes with a slightly bitter oak and fermented cherry aftertaste.The oak adds alot to this beer. My favorite New Glarus brew, one of my favorite beers overall. Its really almost perfect. It is kind of acidic though like any beer with some fruity character to it. This bottle is about a year old, never rated it fresh yet. It changes as it ages some but not for the worse, some of the tartness goes away a little.

Update: 2012 batch.
Still as sour and great as ever. One of my favorite beers. Really changed as it warms up.Very heavily carbonated, dont remember that so much.

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of cherries, light funk, and a hint of wood.  Poured amber in color with a large, rocky, off-white/tan head that greatly diminished but lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Sparkling.  Full of tiny particles throughout.  Good lacing.  Flavor is medium to heavily sweet.  Tastes of cherries, oak, light funk, vanilla, malt, and wood.  Medium body.  Slightly sticky texture.  Average carbonation.  Medium sweet, cherry, vanilla, funk, oak finish is lightly sticky.
OLD GABF. A amber brew with white head. Aroma is sour but also sweet caramel. Sweet fruit goes lightly tart sour funky with a bit of caramel. Finishes even more sour.

Bottle:  The aroma consists of moderate sweet/sour cherry, oak, and light vanilla.  It pours a transparent (when held to the light) dark amber with a two finger cream colored head with decent retention.  The flavor starts with a quick dose of sweet cherry.  The finish has tart cherry, oak, light vanilla, and a touch of sour apple.  Its medium bodied with moderate carbonation  and a somewhat soft mouthfeel.  Overall, very tasty and very drinkable, but it comes across more like a fruit (cherry) beer than a Sour Ale.

bottle at daks on 1/2/11.

this is quite similar to the 06 version  except it feels a little tamed down. less sourness, less vanilla, less malty depth and less complexity. it is still very good... 8/4/8/4/16

Bottle on 01/15/2011 at the 13th Richmond Gathering. Clear amber body with a small creamy white head. Big woody aroma with spice and caramel. Slighty tart woody flavor wiht spice, caramel and fruit. Medium light body with moderately high carbonation.

brownish red pour with a short lived khaki head.  aroma is slightly sweet with just a hint of sourness.  flavor is similar to aroma with some apples and cherry tartness.  somewhat dry. not quite as deep a flavor or as well rounded as the earlier edition.

In short: A decent sweet and spicy fruity beer (cranberries, apples and cherries).  Not much of a sour ale
How: Bottle 12oz.  A few times.  This rating for a bottle that is almost 1 year of age.  Bottle sent to me by changeup45, thanks a lot Gary
The look: Partly cloudy golden-red body topped by a small beige head.  Nice shinny color
In long: Rather un-sour nose with sweet apples, cranberries and vanilla.  Taste is sweet cranberry juice, sweet red apples, liquorices, vanilla, light notes of maraschino cherries,  spices (nutmeg, cloves, etc.).  I remember the original release of this beer being more of an approximation of a Flemish sour.  This beer is a not-style spicy sweet fruit beers with a little cherry tartness here and there.  Not much of a sour ale.  So how does it fare as a fruit beer?  Ok I guess.  I first had it when it was very fresh after the release and the spices were too prominent.  Now the beer has settled down but it is still not something I enjoyed very much.  I dont understand the ratebeer Sour/Wild classification on this beer.  This is not a Sour/Wild.  This beer is a sweet and slightly spicy beer, you cant argue with it.  Well you can, but arguing with a beer or any other inanimate object is a waste of time.

red woody pour with a thing offwhite head.  Aroma is buttery popcorn, cherry, wood, sour wood.  slippery greasy palate.  Flavor is at first sour and vanilla cherry, but melts into a mess of margarine, wood, and tart cherry syrup.  Pretty unpleasant.  Disappointed as I was looking forward to this.
Pours deep dark red with a thin white head. Aroma is buttery barrel. Flavor is butter. Butter butter butter, and then margarine. Slippery, greasy palate. Awful drainpour.

12 oz bottle, pours out a deep amber into my delirium snifter with a wispy whitish head. full aroma of tart wildness and cherry sweetness, an interesting interplay between sensory categories. malt, chocolate, smoke, tannins all appear, and its a very inviting beer to smell. flavors make an entertaining transition from the tip of the tongue all the way down: acids, malt, oak, chocolate and cherry, showcasing the entire spectrum with the notable exception of hops which do some excellent--and unheralded--balancing work. Everything dries out except for some lingering cherry flavors which seem to waft across the palate all the way out so I can still smell it. Excellent brew!

Im not really familiar with sours. Is this really considered a sour or a fruit beer? Man im a little too buzzed right now and the beer has been gone for a couple hours. It was decent though. Apple and grape flavors going on. Not bad. L

12oz bottle. Pours a clear, reddish brown color with an off white head.  Aroma is fruity, cherry, and a little funk.  Medium on the palate with average carbonation.  Flavor is sour, cherry, with a clean sour finish.  Never had the 2006 version, but this one is pretty tasty.

Pours reddish brown with a thin off white head.  Smells of cherries, oaky, some acidic sourness.  Tastes tarte and sour with some residual sugar and some bourbony hints.  Much different from the 2006.

Sampled side-by-side the 2006 vintage.  The 2010 vintage pours to an orange-ish hued red body.  More orange than 2006.  Same thin creamy starch white head.  Similar aroma to what I recorded for 2006.  Although, the 2006 has changed with more of a lactic type of aroma.  Cherries, subtle yellow apples, juniper berries, vanilla, and chocolate kit kats.  The flavors are nearly identical.  Ill throw anything thats currently different into the bucket of age.  The flavor is cherries, subtle granny smith apples, caramel, Ferrero Rocher candies, vanilla, and shortbread.  Tart, yet sweet and coating, medium body and 20 second finish.  Not quite as good, but still most excellent!

Same bottle as pictured. Poured dark reddish brown with little head. Aroma was really funky, smelled different than other sours. Taste was mostly sour and funk but was very straightforward and not overpowering. Really well done in my opinion.

Bottle, first thought was this doesnt smell very good. the beer looks like a sour, it taste like one too but the smell was hurting. The sourness wasnt too over power it was pretty drinkable, good offering, would have again, thanks nate for the bottle

Huge thanks to BeerFMAndy for sending a bottle of this out my way. Served in a Captain Lawrence tulip.

Pour yields a brew with a dark bronze color and a really good white head. Moderate lacing as it goes down. The nose is smells of slight oxidation, though it fits with the cherry. Theres also some mild oak and some lightly-sweet bready malt. Cherry comes back through, especially as it warms. The flavor hits notes of cherry with a bit of oak and light vanilla. A light touch of acid, though not much. The sourness is mostly confined to the finish. Pretty good, though not as good as their standard fruit offerings.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-11-2011
12oz bottle. Dark murky brown pour with no head and what seemed to be low carbonation. Aroma was full of spice, apple, cider and sweet malt. Flavor held much of the same qualities. A delicious beer.

Bottle at Papsøs - Thanks. Clear amber - white head. Coconut, american oak, fruity,light sourish, red berries, coconut, acid, light solvents, cherry notes, lacto notes, dryness, apples, caramel notes.
Pours light brown with notes of fried fruits and a dense malt sweetness.  Notes of cherries and vanilla drive the sour based flavors that show off the malt nicely.

Bottle at Papsø.
Clear orange coloured with a medium sized off-white head.
Sweet and fruity aroma of caramel, dried fruits, oak and vanilla.
Swet and fruity flavour of caramel, apples, dried fruits, oak and vanilla.
Fruity and oaky finish.

Bottle at Papsø. Pours hazy amber with a medium off white head. The aroma is sweet fruity with notes of acid, raisins and oak. The flavour is sweet fruit, acid, light spice, oak and dark fruit. Light cardemon finish.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours cloudy dark orange to brown with a small white head. Aroma is wineous, spiced and fruity. Slight cherry touch to almondish. Dry, slight phenolic and solid wineous fruity. Slight nutty note too. Mild acidic touch. Ends dry and fruity to almondish.

Bottled. An amber beer with a thin lazing white head. The  aroma has notes of vinegar, malt, cinnamon, and wood. The flavor is sweet  with notes of vinegar, caramel, straw, and wood, leading to a tart finish.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of Doodler. Pours a clear amber with a small off-white head. Sweet, tart berry aroma with a sweet oaky touch. Medium body, sweet fruity and vanilla-like again with a slight tartness. Fairly complex and pleasant. 270411
Bottled. Amber coloured. Unclear. Dense light brown head. Aroma of wood, grape, sourness, spice, berries. Flavour of berries, sweetness, spice, wood, sourness. Medium to full bodied. Berry sour end.

Thanks to Pellinore1 for sending me this bottle. I have been looking forward to trying this one. 

The beer pours an amber color with a white head. The aroma is very nice. I get a lot of cherry and brown sugar notes, as well as some vanilla. The beer also smells quite tart. 

The flavor is more of the same. The predominant flavor is cherries with some maple and caramel malt notes. The beer is semi-tart, but overall it does not taste as tart as it smells. The fruit and tartness mix very well together and make the beer extremely drinkable. 

Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Very glad I got to try this one.
I think this is the beer that opened my eyes to different styles.  Reminds me of a sour, but I cant call it one.  This is not my "normal" type of beer but I could drink this all the time!

Pours an amber/red with a very small white head which dissipates relatively quickly.  The smell is almost like a Chianti with notes of sour fruit and Talc.  The effervescence is tight and sharp which works really well with the not-overpowering apple/tart/apricot flavor.  The bitter kick follows a sour punch and the knockout is the long, mild, flavorful finish.

Bottle. Thanks to Secret Santa! Pours a clear amber reddish color with a small off-white head. Has a sour malty slightly sweetish caramel aroma. Sweetish fruity slightly tart sour funky flavor with hints of caramel. Has a sweetish fruity and slightly tart funky finish.
I could drink this all the time!  Brett like nose with sour cherries.  A very mild and soft oak and tart sourness with fruits.  Loved it wish I could drink this every nite
Copper white head aroma caramel sourness vinegar. Flavor is light sourness cereal caramel vinegar. Not as sour as the last release but still good.

Bottle @ home, courtesy of kbutler1. Thanks! Dark red vIolet appearance with a tan colored head. Sweet, cherry, vinous, oaky, vanilla aroma. Quite sour, but incredibly delicious cherry flavor on top of mildly oaky, vanilla taste. Sour and quite sweet cherry, vanilla finish. Not super sour. Excellent beer!

I drank this from a 12oz bottle into my Rochefort glass...The beer pours super carbonated, tons of bubbles on the glass like a sparkling water, but a disappointing flat light tan head. The beer is a brownish pink, not very attractive looking...The aroma is really light, gives off only a little light sour, but thats it...The taste has a lot more going here, its light sweet and tart cherries, the sour funkyness disappears. Its a lighter feeling and tasting verison of the Belgian Red. It lacks the complexity though, just light sweet and a little tart...The feel is really light and watery. Easy to drink but I cant imagine having more than of these before getting bored.

Overall a light boring fruit beer.

120z bottle from the brewery. Cherries, light acetic, wood, dark malt and dark fruits. Taste is cherries, wood/vanilla and a sweet maltiness followed by a slightly sour, tart and tannic finish. This is a nicely balanced beer with a wealth of delightful flavors. Although it is more restrained than most sour brown ales, it is not a bad thing. This would make a good daily drinker.

Pours a reddish copper color with an orange head that disappears quickly. The aroma is a heavy dose of fermented cherries, cherry syrup, and touches of vanilla. The flavor has lots of sweet cherry syrup with some vanilla caramel, and wild yeast. More sweet than sour, but well balanced. Tastes bigger than the 5.5% would suggest.

Superb aroma, vanilla caramel, dried (but still a bit moist and luscious) red and stone fruits with tiny hints of fine sherry vinegar.  This is a revelation.  Flavor is not very tart, but it does have a superb flavor.  Fresh, mature grated coconut flesh, vanilla, granola, dried cherries.  Totally unique and really astounding.

Tasted on 3/17/11 from a 12oz bottle purchased at Discount Liquor.  Pours cloudy light red, trending toward pink, with a thick beige head that slowly recedes to even lace, leaving lace along the inside of the glass as it goes.  The nose is awesome!  This smells almost like a white Burgundy wine with vanilla and caramel oak, cinnamon, light elements of earth, cheese, and barnyard, a bit of vinegar, and tart lemon notes.  The flavor is somewhat sweet with caramel, vanilla, and ripe cherries up front, moving to good vinegar and some tartness, and back to the cherries, cinnamon, and vanilla on the back.  The body is medium and oily with average carbonation and a long, complex finish that features the cinnamon, cherries, vinegar, vanilla, and some nuttiness all very prominently.

Via trade with Rayl101.  Aroma is tart cheery, funk, oak.  Very nice.  The appearance is a translucent dark amber, off-white head.  The flavor is tart cherries, sharp vinegar, oak, vanilla, nice mix of varied flavors.  The finish is sharp vinegar, cherries, like couch syrup.  Medium to medium/thick in body.  Very nice.  Thanks, Kevin.

Bottle: &nbsp Reddish amber, some fine sediment floats about, thin spritzy head, spotty lacing. &nbsp Very faint Black Cherry nose, also fairly strong Oak. &nbsp Reminds me of a weaker Belgian Red on Oak. &nbsp Soft unripened fruitiness up front, slight oak. &nbsp This seems more of a Flanders Red than a Sour Ale. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate, although it feels a little thin on the backside. &nbsp Finish remains tart, albeit there is this unripened cherry fruitiness that abounds. &nbsp This is like a less sweet yet more tart version of their Belgian Red. &nbsp Pretty happy with this one. &nbsp Thanks to Skyview for this tasty bottle!

Bottle via trade from kbutler1 as an excellent extra.  Aroma is sweet with a little sour that I think Im only getting because I know the style of beer.  The beer pours a nice dark orange/amber with minimal head that dissipates quickly.  I definitely pick up the sour in the first sip.  This dissipates to a sweet and overt vanilla flavor at the finish.  I didnt think this combination would be pleasing but it very much is.  Overall it is a very unique beer and one that I find refreshing in terms of the sour style.  Glad people are exploring new avenues with this style.  For whatever reason this beer very much reminds me of fall possibly because of similar characteristics I pick up from the Bruerys BA Autumn Maple.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text:
2010 version. Says its a fruit beer on here, not sure if it is a full blown fruit beer.

It pours into my chalice a vibrant reddish orange. It has a decent white head that quickly recedes it leaves a bit of lacing.

The smell is very oaky, for some reason the oak scents in New Glarus beers are a bit more blunt than other beers. There is a light fruity character, but no sourness.

This is a very sweet beer, almost cloying. It is fruity but not overly so. It has a nice sourness. Over all this is the oak which again, is blunt. I dont know if it is the barrels but the oaky New Glarus products just seem off for some reason to me.

This really reminds me of Monks cafe which I find a terrible representation of the style, this one like that one is just too sweet and the oak just doesnt meld properly.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-20-2010 02:24:45

12oz Bottle. Thanks Kevin! Coconut, pineapple, plum and acid aroma. Moderately strong, enjoyable and thorough. Immediately, I notice a high level of sweetness. Im enjoying the heavy vanilla and coconut character to this beer, but good lord is it sweet and that sweetness is not balanced by the acidity. In fact, the acidity just washes out, practially. Chewy, malty, sweet, overly clean, and, sadly, not that stunning of a Sour Ale. Flavors are there, texture and balance are not.

12 oz bottle. Pours a deep ruby color with a small creamy light tan froth. Aroma is a nice blend of sweet cherry and vanilla and light tart citrus rind, woodiness and some funk. Flavor starts with an initial burst of nice sour cherries, picking up some strong oaky wood and vanilla notes. The sourness fades towards the finish with a sweet and lightly grainy and earthy character. Very clean finish. Medium body and a sharp carbonation. Excellent sour, well balanced. Not mouth puckering but complex and delicious.

Bottle. Pours slightly hazed reddish amber.  Thin, light tan/peach suds.  Not overly sour but slightly so in the nose..more sweetness underneath though I reckon, some maraschino cherry, maybe some canned pineapple and/or peaches, and a little spice...something lighter cinnamon...maybe just a dust nutmeg or allspice, or something. I dont know.   Flavors kind of tarten things..that maraschino cherry thing comes to the forfront, almost grenadine-like, with that undetermined touch of spice...it really comes from he background of the nose to complete center the flavors..interestesting.  Interesting beer...its got a similar cherry flavor as the belgian red, but different at the same time...while the flanders red character of the beer makes it quite different than belgian red.

Big thanks to phaleslu for passing this winner along to me.  Pours light brown/amber with a reddish hue and a nice beige head.  The aroma has lots of oak and vanilla to the point of almost being milky.  There is some sourness, sharp fruits, hazelnuts, melon, coconut and cream.  It has a medium smooth lush body with soft flowing carbonation.  The taste starts off with coconut, vanilla, oak, cream, sweet cherries, raspberries, mild spice, some sourness and a candy-like aspect.  The finish has lush cherries and pepper added in.  This seems like a cross between a traditional Flanders Red and New Glarus Belgian Red.  A really nice beer.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2012 Tasted with the Mikes on the worlds best beer day.  So many of these brews were blatant with the flavors.  This one was not.  It was subtle everywhere.  Light nose, with bits of cherry/vinegar, but only hints.  Taste was even, again with the subtlety.  I need access to more than a bottle of this to be able to break it down.
Pale copper color with foamy off-white head.  Lightly tart and sour aroma with a candy sweetness.  The body is again very light with a solid sour flavor.

Thanks Richmond crew! transparent red-tan, the thinnest cream ring. Nose of wheat, brown sugar, bit of tart cherry. Sweeter, muddled flavor, bit of malt and cardboard on the palate through finish, some apple skin and cherry and sugar in finish. Bit thin and clinging. Meh, the blend of sugar and sour works as neither is well developed here.
Pours amber with a small head. Has very little lacing. Aroma is cherries,wood and a bit of vinegar. Taste is that of cherries with a tart finish. Overall an excellent beer.

Small offwhite head, fair retention and minimal lacing. Hazy amber orange colored brew. Juicey, funky nose, tart pungent with notes of wood and fruit, cherries and spices. Body is med/light, soft carbonation ,lightly oily, nicely acidic, tangy slightly. Good flavors of cherry and lumber, faint resinous notes, nice tang, wood, faint vanilla, caramel is tastey and lightly sweet. Lasting spicey finish, juicey nice. Props to motortoddhead for the bottle! Thanks bro!

Bottle and served in Bells snifter, tasted next to my last bottle of the 2006 version: Pours a reddish amber hue with a fading fizzy head and minimal lace. The aroma has notes of wild and tart cherries, red wine vinegar, vanilla bean, French oak tannins, and some Cinnamon and herbal spices. So far the two are strikingly similar, perhaps the 2006 is a tad darker and a bit more forceful on the nose but I am picking up the exact same esters and vapours in them both.  The taste starts with some tart and sweet cherries, even some cassis along with layers of vanilla toned oak and Cinnamon like spice. Hint of pale biscuit and caramel malts here and there. The tannic nature of the 2010 seems more upfront than in the 2006 and the 2010 is far less acidic nor tart. The mouth feel is medium-bodied with a slight slickness and dry oaky finish. A bit under carbonated if you ask me. Final verdict: While this latest version of the Unplugged Enigma is still a nice brew that I would gladly try again it is still far less interesting a sour ale than the original Enigma which I had rated a 4.1 back in May 5, 2007. All told I still think I would rather have the 1st Sour Brown Ale recipe over either (fresh of course) .

Hazy red brown color with a small, off white head that left  nice lacing on the glass,  Aroma of cherries, wood, caramel malts, nuts, and some red wine vinegar.  Taste of sweeter cherries, light acidity, toffee, some caramel, and a tart finish.
Richmond 13th.  Aroma is interesting, sour cherry and worcestishire (sp?).  Flavor is more sweet cherry and an interesting vanilla finish.  Very good.

(Sample Date: 1/15/2011   Source:Other)   Woody malty with hints of cherry fruitiness. Clear orange amber with little head. Woody sourness with some cherry notes. Malty sweetness. Medium body and mouth feel. Finish is medium with woody sourness lingering. Very tasty.
Sampled at the Richmond Gather XIII.  Holy hell, this is VERY sweet. But gooooood. Cherry, and backsweetened. Girls would love this hsit. fun.

Bottle. Holy mother. Nose is INCREDIBLE -- brandy, buckwheat honey, cherries, vanilla, caramel. Pours a rich gold -- almost brandy colored again -- with a very light head. Taste is incredible -- more of the same as the nose, with rich sourness (if thats possible) and some faint bitterness on the close. In-freaking-credible.
12 ounce bottle from HB Mason.  dynamic taste, excellent flavor. could drink a few of these

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2015 Clear amber pour off white beige head .... aroma is sour, pear, vanilla and fruity cherry cake like ... Taste is of fruity sour tart cherry and berries with dry oak with vanilla with a sour dry finish ... Nice malty backbone with some pear in there as well..... very tasty brew, dry sweet and a slight bitter fruit .... Lovely fruit flavors and very sessionable

Bottle in trade with Fear025.  pours a deep copper with a thinner oily tan head.  Note: this sucker is the last to lurk in the upstairs fridge...mainly cause the pickles have been secluding it next to the maraschino cherries.  Nose hints of a gentle sour ale even before I have the brains to read the label.  Some fusel tones then rich viscous fruit hit the tongue with a slight sour finish.  Plums and some soft wet wood circle the mouth.  Slow lazy carbonation.  Body is ciderific and light to medium.  Thats all I got folks.

Bottle pours hazy amber with a fizzy head.  Aroma is dominated by notes of cherry with underlying hints of oak and funk.  Flavor shows basically the same.  This reminds me somewhat of dissident, just quite a bit less spicy.  Overall body is moderate, sweet, and lightly acidic.
bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  poured amber with a white head.  aroma was cherry and caramel.  flavor was cherry, caramel, and cinnamon.

Bottle drank in our room at the Pfister, Milwaukee. (Great party Simon. Congrats!) Medium brown color with a tan head. Softly sour aroma with a bit of malt and dark cherry in the background. Flavor is tart and sustained by a bit of caramel and fresh cherry notes.

Bottle received from Ratman.  Pours hazy brown with a small, fizzy and rocky white head, short retention with light lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, caramel, toast), light hops (earthy), and average esters (apple/pear) with notes of vanilla, lightly charred oak, cherry, fig, and brown sugar.  Flavor is heavy malt (cookie, caramel, toast), light hops (earthy), and average esters (apple/pear) with notes of cherry, fig, port, oak, smoke, brown sugar, and vanilla.  Full body, low warmth and creaminess, medium carbonation with a dry finish.

A- Body is a transparent ruby red hue. Pours with a 1 finger or so soapy white head. Head eventually fades to a thin collar.

S-Sour cherry, deep dark fruit, oak, and a hint of vanilla. Oak is soaked. Nice deep and balanced

T-Sour cherry balanced with soaked oak upfront very well-hints of vanilla come forward as well. Finish is similar to the initial flavor but the cherry fades a bit and the oak comes through more. 

M- Medium to high tingly carbonation and a medium weight full body.

D- This is a very good, rich fruit beer. The balance between the cherry and barrel chracteristics is wonderful. Much better than wisconsin belgian red and more tame as well. I would like this to be a bit wilder but its very good as is! Another great job by NG!

Serving type: bottle
